I hoped I could get a clue that would invalidate (or at least make me question) my personal paranormal experience. I'd been a skeptic (and still am pretty skeptic) regarding all paranormal phenomena. One night I was unable to sleep because I had slept at noon, but it was still late and I had to get up the day after. I was at my step-grandma's house, in the living room's bed. There was a balcony, the doors to which were open, and in the middle of the room there was a table. Normal eastern european living room dining table. As I was fidgeting on my phone, trying to find sleep where there's none I hear this SLAP smack on the table. I immediately turn around, and nothing was there. I went out the balcony, street was completely empty. I went back in bed, frankly not really worried because I was convinced if it was actually a ghost it was of my step-dad's father who at the time I remembered died in that room and frankly I had no reason to worry he had quarrel with me. So I turned my phone off and turned my back to the room which is when I felt it. A drumming, on the bedframe. 4 beats, drumming like someone impatient would. Frankly, I was bewildered, but even more than that excited because I finally encountered a ghost. That's gotta be some story to tell, especially since people knew me as a skeptic who would first follow through every logical possibility that would come to his mind. After a while I did manage to fall asleep, though it was pretty late and I just cancelled my next day plans so I could sleep in.

The next day I woke up near noon, rather poorly rested, went into the kitchen and had lunch for breakfast. Chatted a bit with that grandma, then I felt sleepy so I went back into my room and laid in bed, back to the wall. And I felt the regular breathing of someone fast asleep on the back of my neck. The only window was on the opposite side of the room, and the bed itself has a rather tall bedframe, it reaches way higher than your head when you lay flat so it would be really unlikely the breathing was currents from the door.

Thing is, alone I could just chalk these phenomena up to something or other (though the table slap was so cllear it would be a fair bit difficult to justify) , but all together it seems like a case of "if you hear hoofbeats think horses".

I don't expect anyone to just up and believe me, and I do not mind potential explanations other than "oh you were just tired, your mind played tricks on you" and that's that because frankly those are non-arguments (not to mention that, again, I was quite restless and rested) and can be said about every paranormal phenomenon that doesn't happen in one's presence and direct observattion. But for what it's worth, I'm pretty certain I've experienced the paranormal that night, at 19 years old.

I personally don't believe in ghosts, for one thing: why would there only be "human" ghosts if such a phenomenon existed? For another, why would we have to guess at history from available remaining sources when we could just interview a ghost who lived during a certain era, maybe with a ouiji board? But most of all, if you look at mankind and our infinite creativeness at explaining phenomena we do not understand then the answer to me is quite clear that ghosts are very unlikely to be a real thing. I mean, how many times in history has a human explanation for a phenomenon we didn't understand been correct? Lightning = god of thunder, will-o-the-wisp = fairy fire in the hands of a goblin who wishes to lead you to your doom etc. We're amazingly creative and inventive, but unless we actually properly investigate and find the scientific explanation, we're usually way off base XD

I have been telling people for years that so-called paranormal phenomena is just generated by the brain.
As 'lay people' we don't understand the workings of the brain and most people have no understanding of the power of suggestion/influence. If you are someone easily frightened by horror movies then you are much more likely to believe in ghost and spirits.
Many people are simply not cynical enough to dismiss much of the video 'evidence' provided by 'victims' and are willing to believe without doubt that the story teller is being genuine. For my money, I'd bet the vast majority are fake and set up.

Don't get me wrong, I am not saying I know the truth. I am open minded about most things... I did see a guy disappear some years ago, not part of a show or video, but out on the streets of Hastings, UK. The guy was riding a unicycle, wearing very unusual clothes and tapping on a hand-held device. He cycled past a bus shelter out of view and didn't reappear the other side. I walked to the shelter to look but he was just gone.
I try not to let this freak me out as I am sure that, somehow, it was an issue in my own brain causing this phenomena, but on a conscious level I cannot understand what happened - I had not taken my eyes off him at all.
The brain, in spite of all that we do know, scientifically, is a mysterious object and maybe we will never fully understand how perception relates to reality.

I'm 24 years old now, this happened when I was 13. It was around 11 PM, I was lying down on my bed having trouble sleeping. My room wasn't in absolute darkness since my window lets in a little bit of light from the outside and, needless to say, my eyes were already used to my surroundings; everything was covered in faint blueish light and clearly visible.

I was getting a bit anxious and frustrated for not being able to sleep, I had to go to school the next day. I looked at the wall on my right, tried to close my eyes one more time and suddenly I felt something pushed my left leg. I immediately turned towards it. To my surprise, there was a girl (she looked around 11 or 12) standing right next to my bed, looking at me. At first, I didn't get scared thinking it was my sister that came into my room, because I left the door open. As I tried to whisper her name, I realized it wasn't her. That genuinely gave me chills. I was paralyzed.

I had never seen this person before in my life. She was a bit taller and older than my sister, who was 8 at the time. The girl had medium, straight, black hair (and my sister's was very long). She had that classic diamond face shape, dark eyes, tiny nose and little mouth. She was wearing white pajamas.

She looked me in the eye and got a bit closer, then leaned towards me and smiled at me with a serene and cute look in her eyes. I know, it's really weird and creepy, but somehow that made me feel relieved. Then she stood up straight again went back a few steps and faded away like it was nothing.

I was astonished and still scared. I didn't sleep a single minute that night. In the morning, I couldn't stop thinking about it. I was repeating it over and over again in my mind. Hell I couldn't stop thinking about it for weeks, and barely slept the first week.

I didn't tell anyone until a few months later, I just didn't think they would believe me, and rightfully so.

Btw, this story doesn't end here. Other people have seen her too. I mean, the descriptions are almost identical but I'm not 100% sure it was the same girl.

So, what do you guys think? Did you experience something similar?

Btw, this looks pretty much exactly like what she was wearing: https://m.es.aliexpress.com/item/32370721752.html?trace=wwwdetail2mobilesitedetail3

re Sleep Paralysis. I’ve experienced this phenomenon far too many times and every single time it’s equally terrifying. The experience is more complicated than the explanation used in the video, with feelings of dread and low level, always menacing, sounds coming before the figures become visible. The sound is so terrifying it seems as if it alone will kill you. In my experiences there are often strange and complicated symbols that fill the air, something like if maths symbols and hieroglyphs married and had children. These symbols move rapidly, and it seems as if there is a message in them which, if I manage to solve, will forestall the coming invasion of “visitors”. Of course, solving the message is impossible, and the figures manifest every time. In my personal experiences there have always been between three and five visible figures, with another (even more terrifying) just too far outside my visual field to see, but it’s presence is felt and heard. I’ve learned how to to break my experience by concentrating on moving my left little finger. If I can move it (which I often can’t), everything dissolves immediately, but it takes a seemingly long time and meanwhile I’m mentally quaking in my hypothetical boots.
I don’t recommend Sleep Paralysis. At all. Ever.

The evidence that the kind of low frequency electromagnetic fields that are present from electrical wires and appliances, or radio waves from phones cause noticable changes in brain firing is really weak I think. I've done research with neuroimaging and if this was really true, you'd expect findings to vary based on things like where in the room a subject was placed, or whether the lights are on or off, but we don't see anything like that. Additionally, MRI studies would be very unethical if this is true, as the use of RF radiation would have unpredictable effects - not to mention every fMRI study being confounded by the presence of EM radiation.

Ultimately, has every single person that has had a paranormal encounter truly had one? No, but such an innumerable amount have that at some point you have to just step back and realize that everything we “know” about the universe is from a limited human understanding, and we do not nor may ever truly know how existence works in its entirety. I'm a sleep paralysis sufferer and the "waking dreams" you experience can feel very, very real and can be quite terrifying. You realise the more outlandish ones are dreams fairly quickly after you fully wake but the ones where you feel someone sitting on your chest and or strangling you while pinning your arms down, or climbing into bed with you and holding you so tightly around the torso that you can't breathe or move are the worst because you think that an actual intruder is attacking you. That takes a while to recover from, believe me.
It was an enormous relief to me and my siblings, who are also sufferers, when we learned about sleep paralysis, how it can manifest and how many people suffer with it. Although I wouldn't wish it on anyone, knowing we weren't alone and that it was a known phenomenon made it a lot easier to cope and recover from the nastier, more realistic episodes. We all suffer instances less frequently the older we get but we all still have them occasionally.

The first three are good possible explanations for some paranormal experiences, but the explanation of sleep paralysis is very speculative, and seems a bit like grasping at straws to me.

The thing is "supernatural" just means we don't/can't (currently) understand it scientifically. In a sense, black holes are supernatural, as we don't currently fully understand them scientifically. You could say diseases were once supernatural, because we hadn't yet understood the viruses and bacteria that cause them.

If you, for a moment, grant the existence of paranormal beings (ghosts, demons, angels, etc.) then what? Do you think they are just inherently illogical and don't exist according to any rules? No. Otherwise they would all be omnipotent and self-contradictory. They are just intelligent entities that our current understanding of biology, chemistry, and physics can grasp yet. In the same way we are to a fish, they are to us.

Perhaps (as the same skepticism, albeit to lesser degree applies) the real reason for the scientific communities poo-pooing of "supernatural" ideas is a natural human arrogance and unwillingness to accept the idea that there may be beings greater than humans out there.

I had an experience about a week or two ago and it was something known as a hypnopompic hallucination. There are two types of these hallucinations both associated with sleep. Hypnagogic hallucinations occur just as a person is falling asleep and hypnopompic occur just as youre waking up. Anyways, I had just opened my eyes in the morning and I saw a face over the top of my head leaning over me from the edge of my bed. Before I reacted to seeing this, the face breathed out over my face like someone fogging up a window pane with their breath when its cold outside. It had grey skin and I think it was a woman. I never felt the breath or anything touching me. But I screamed very weirdly and flipped over onto my hands and knees seeing nothing over the edge of my bed. It was very frightening and I've never experienced anything like it before. However, I immediately ruled it out as my mind playing tricks on me and went back to sleep with no other disturbances to date. Ive never had sleep paralysis or anything of the sort so I guess it makes sense why I was so scared but nonetheless it was a very interesting experience. I've only experienced sleep paralysis once, about 40 years ago. A carpenter bee was boring a hole in my door jamb, causing buzzing and scratching sounds to resonate in the wall. These were amplified by a vaulted ceiling in the stairwell just outside my small bedroom. I "woke up" and discovered I was paralyzed. While I anxiously wondered why, my brain created a rationalization: A burglar was trying to break in, and I was staying quiet and motionless so that if they got in they wouldn't find me and kill me. After a few minutes of terror, I woke up fully and realized none of it was real. I discovered the new hole in my door jamb, which explained the sounds, and everything else became clear. Then I looked for an explanation on the internet and discovered the phenomenon had a name.
There have been a few times in recent years when I have half awoke and found my body wouldn't move, but since I now know what's happening to cause it, I can will myself fully awake and get up. (Which is important, because it usually happens when I need to use the bathroom.)

What I love about this is that it concisely lays out the scientific evidence for all the debunking AND provides sources. Awesome video, SciShow! This also made me think of something else. Specifically, there are a few points where you reference EMF and how that may (probably does) account for lots of different purported ghostly experiences.


That being said, I feel that EMF is very underrated in terms of its potential negative health impacts. You laid out exactly how it can cause problems for people with existing issues, and by extension, it seems reasonable to think that it might CAUSE issues. If someone is sensitive/susceptible, that means simply that it is easier for them to be affected by something. Caffeine sensitivity doesn't mean that caffeine is a super stimulant, but it is for those people. Conversely, if you can DEFINITELY see the negative effects of EMF on some people, then it is probably causing negative effects on others that just don't manifest those symptoms as clearly. You did mention this, but I feel like that is the exact issue with 5G.


5G is going to be MUCH more intense of an EMF exposure than anything else that is currently out there, and it is going to be everywhere in urban areas. In order to get 5G coverage everywhere, there will need to be 5G antennas EVERYWHERE, because it only does LOS and has trouble penetrating solid structures. That means people are going to be continuously bombarded by it if they live in an urban area. If there are people who are already sensitive to EMF now, imagine how many people will be sensitive to it when the exposure rate and intensity sky rockets all around the world. And why? So people can watch videos faster and not wait on downloads...

I had sleep paralysis once about 20 years ago. Back then, I had NO idea that sleep paralysis even existed. I had the whole gamut of hallucinations. It was absolutely terrifying! I abruptly woke from a nightmare and just laid there. I started feeling a tingling sensation in my feet and it slowly worked it's way all the way up my body until it got to my ears. Once it reached my ears, I started hearing a weird sound, like water flowing through pipes...After that, I felt people poking me through the blankets, repeatedly...then I felt someone messing with the blankets at my feet. It felt more mischevious to me than anything, like little kids playing a game or something. I don't remember being super scared at that point...just having a WTF moment...But then a woman came right up to my face and stared at me...she looked like me, but she had a super stern look on her face and she was completely gray..like out of a black and white film. THAT was scary. Then it all went away. I remember lying there thinking "OMG, I have to get up and walk across the room to turn the light on!!"...I didn't sleep in my bed for about 6 months after that. I was absolutely petrified it would happen again...Sleep paralysis is no joke.

Story time.

When I was around 8-9 me, and my whole family were eating dinner around 2 in the afternoon. My grandma was talking about some random stuff that I don't remember, and out of the blue a really loud thud happened in the attic. It sounded like someone dropped a 50 pound book perfectly flat on the floor. We all just sat there silently, and pretty much everyone looked at our grandpa. He was kind of like the head person of our family so we were all waiting for what he was gonna do or say. A few seconds passed, and he visibly looked disturbed(never seen him have this look before) then he blurted out in a joking manner "oh that's just George being noisy!" Probably 30 seconds after he said that, another loud slamming noise happened, then it sounded like something heavy was being dragged across the floor in the attic. Grandpa yelled "shut up George" then we all awkwardly started eating again. We were all kids so anyone that tried to talk about it got scolded so it took a good 15 years for anyone in my family to even talk about it.

For clarification the house we were living in was an old farm house completely made of rocks. There was no electricity, and no running water. There was a well in the basement(always creeped me out) We did check the attic after dinner, and there was dust everywhere, and nothing was moved. Pretty sure it was crazy completely empty besides a few old jackets being on the floor

I experience Sleep Paralysis, and it started 11 years ago before I even knew what Sleep Paralysis was. The very first time it happened, I saw a person in my room with me, a woman with black hair in a red dress. Leaned over my computer on my desk she was clattering away on the keyboard like she didn't know how to type. Then she turned around and walked over to me, but since i'm Legally Blind, everything in the room was blurry, including her face. She leaned over me and stuck her tongue out, right up near my face, like she was mocking me that I couldn't move or do anything.
After a couple minutes, I snapped awake. After that, I've had sleep paralysis events ever since, especially if I 'think about them' while I'm trying to get to sleep.
I've never seen that woman again. 10 years later I learned about 'The Hag' or the 'Mare' who comes and visits people during sleep paralysis experiences.
I... was freaked out.
But, I've never seen her again, and can still get myself into these 'trapped' sensations of being between sleep and awake.
They're extremely uncomfortable. I've found out that by clamping my eyes shut, and holding them shut for about 10 seconds, i'll usually wake up though.
So if you read this, and experience it too, try that, it might help.
